name: Bruce Mau
biography:
Bruce Mau, born in Sudbury, Ontario in 1959 attended Ontario College of Art and Design between 1978 and 1989. He founded Bruce Mau Design in 1985 and now heads a staff of fifteen. The Studio's work is based in Canada, the United States and Europe.  
From 1991-1993, he served as Creative Director for I.D. Magazine. 
Mau has held various teaching positions at institutions such as the California Institute of the Arts, the University of Toronto, the Getty Research Center for the History of Art and the Humanities, Havard's Graduate School of Design, and Rice University.  Mau has designed books such as Claes Oldenburg and Coosje van Bruggen's "Large Scale Projects" and the Guggenheim Museum's "Frank Gehry Guggenheim Museum Bilbao." He also co-wrote "S,M,L,XL" with Rem Koolhaas. His design talents have also been explored in exhibition design for the Art Gallery of Ontario, Toronto and collaborations on dance projects with Mikhail Baryshnikov. Most recently he has been involved with publication design for Gagosian Gallery's "Glen Seator," a conceptual program for the National Museum of the Missisippi River, an exhibition concept and installation of "Panorama" for the Vienna 2000 Festival.
Mau has received prestigious awards such as the Chrysler Award for Design Innovation and I.D. magazine's The I.D. Forty (1998).
